none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. Smith (), June 28, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. Smith (), June 28, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Margin: V]

Galveston, Texas
June 28, /90.

Dear Prof. McInnis;
I was sorry I did
not see you to bid you
good bye befor I left the
College, but had to go to town
the day I left and it was
quite late before I got
back, so hadn't time to go
down to the house that
night.

I didn't get things to rights
and ready to leave until
12 o'clock that night and
found the car crowded, so
that I could not get either
a sleeper or a seat, hence

**Transcription Analysis and Verification** Alright, let's get down to it. I've got this handwritten letter in front of me, and my task is to provide a transcription, making sure it's accurate down to the smallest detail. My expertise is knowing what *should* be written, and what is *actually* written, so the task is to bridge those things, and create the most accurate transcript possible. First, I'm noting the details. In the top right, there's a mark - a "V", which I assume is some kind of filing notation. Then comes the header, "Galveston, Texas / June 28, /90." - pretty clear, though I'm keeping a mental note of those potential quirks in the '90's. Next, the salutation: "Dear Prof. McInnis;". The 'M' looks right, the 'c' is small, 'Innis' seems legit. Now, into the body. Each line is getting a thorough look: * "I was sorry I did" - straightforward. * "not see you to bid you" - again, easy. * "good bye befor I left the" - hold up! The word "befor" is throwing me a bit. It is *befor* in the image, so I'll write *befor*. * "College, but had to go to town" - capital 'C' in College, as expected. * "the day I left and it was" - good. * "quite late before I got" - now the *before* has a clear 'e', see the difference in my handwriting analysis! * "back, so hadn't time to go" - 'hadn't' - the apostrophe is implied, so I'll transcribe. * "down to the house that" - okay. * "night." - good. * "I didn't get things to rights" - "rights", as in, *to rights*, idiom. * "and ready to leave until" - all good. * "12 o'clock that night and" - here's where it gets interesting, that word after "o'clock" is messy. It looks like "that" written over something else. But I have checked this thoroughly! It's *that*. * "found the car crowded, so" - okay. * "that I could not get either" - good. * "a sleeper or a seat, hence" - the word "hence" is a bit cut off. I'll include it as "hence" with the implied meaning. Now, let's format it. I'll maintain the line breaks, use `

[Margin: V]

Galveston, Texas
June 28, /90.

Dear Prof. McInnis;
I was sorry I did
not see you to bid you
good bye befor I left the
College, but had to go to town
the day I left and it was
quite late before I got
back, so hadn't time to go
down to the house that
night.

I didn't get things to rights
and ready to leave until
12 o'clock that night and
found the car crowded, so
that I could not get either
a sleeper or a seat, hence

```

I reached Galv, considerably
the worst for wear.
Found my North Texas girl
here in advance of me, and
have had a very pleasant
time.

The exhibits, I think re-
ceived very little attention,
I guess it was just as well
the college made none, tho'
it might have shown well
by contrast.

I think this has been
more of a pleasure trip
than one of business, to
a great majority of the
teachers. Next time they
will visit Austin.

You will soon have
the Board with you
again, I sincerely hope
that whatever action

**Transcription Complete** Okay, here's what I've got. The task seems straightforward: transcribe this handwritten letter, and I've broken down my process. First, I had to analyze the image itself – the script, the condition of the paper (it's a bit aged with some fold lines), and the language (English, as expected). The biggest hurdle was the handwriting. I then went through it line by line. The first line immediately snagged me: "I reached Galv. considerably." It looked a little messy, a bit cursive. The first word in the location "Galv." gave me pause. Was it really "Galv" as in Galveston? It kind of looked like "Isalo" at first glance, or "Galo" but the context ("North Texas girl," "visit Austin") strongly suggested that "Galv." was the correct interpretation, meaning Galveston. I had to look closely. The handwriting has a loop, a downstroke, another loop, and a small loop or dip at the end, so I went through it visually and semantically, trying to reconcile the actual letters with what I know. Given that, I decided to stick with "Galv.", assuming it was an abbreviation. As I proceeded, "The exhibits... received very little attention..." caught my attention. Then the line with a word that looked like "tho'", which I determined was an informal "though," with an apostrophe. As I got further into it, "Next time they will visit Austin" required some close examination. The first part looked like "Next tiche" to me, but clearly the intended word was "time." After I compared similar words and the handwriting style (specifically the "m" in the word "time"), it seemed like the writer may have been sloppy in forming it. Again, context wins out. I carefully considered the other text, noting capital letters ("North Texas", "Austin", "Board"), and punctuation (the apostrophe). The final transcription is as follows:

I reached Galv, considerably
the worst for wear.
Found my North Texas girl
here in advance of me, and
have had a very pleasant
time.

The exhibits, I think re-
ceived very little attention,
I guess it was just as well
the college made none, tho'
it might have shown well
by contrast.

I think this has been
more of a pleasure trip
than one of business, to
a great majority of the
teachers. Next time they
will visit Austin.

You will soon have
the Board with you
again, I sincerely hope
that whatever action

they may take will be
for the best interests of
the college. I very much
fear that the college will
have a rather hard time
of it for some time.

I have decided not to ap-
ply formally for Associate
Prof. Math. If, however, they
do not leave you Prof. Math
and are willing to let me
try the work for a year
I will undertake it, and
will do all in my power
to do the work well.

I have sent my books over
to Huntsville, and shall
begin on the first to go
over all the "first class"
work before Sept. If I get
through in time, I ex
pect to take a flying

**Image Analysis and Transcription Process** Okay, here's what I'm thinking, as I dive into this task. The user wants me to transcribe text from a handwritten letter. I see it's cursive, likely penned or penciled. I've got to read carefully, especially since the script is a bit faded. It looks like a personal or professional letter, maybe discussing college stuff, a job application for Associate Professor of Math, and moving books to Huntsville. I'm starting line by line: * **Line 1:** I see "they may take will be." Context is important here – seems like it continues a previous thought. * **Line 2:** "for the best interests of" – confirms the flow. * **Line 3:** "the college. I very much" – noting that the 'o's look like 'a's or 'u's. The handwriting can be tricky. * **Line 4:** "fear that the college will" – the word 'college' is a recurring challenge. * **Line 5:** "have a rather hard time" – pretty clear. * **Line 6:** "of it for some time." – Ah, the little "it" is faint, but it's the correct idiom, so I'm putting it in. I'm focusing on "of it for some time". * **Line 7:** "I have decided not to ap-" – standard language. * **Line 8:** "ply formally for Associate" – making sure I get the capitalization right on "Associate". * **Line 9:** "Prof. Math. If, however, they" – the abbreviation "Prof." and "Math." need to be accurate. * **Line 10:** "do not leave you Prof. Math" – the meaning is slightly open, but the letters look like "leave." * **Line 11:** "and are willing to let me" – straightforward. * **Line 12:** "try the work for a year" – standard sentence. * **Line 13:** "I will undertake it, and" – also standard. * **Line 14:** "will do all in my power" – making sure every word is there. * **Line 15:** "to do the work well." – standard language. * **Line 16:** "I have sent my books over" – noting that "sent" could be "sut", but given context, it's definitely "sent". * **Line 17:** "to Huntsville, and shall" – Huntsville, need to make sure I am writing it out correctly. * **Line 18:** "begin on the first to go" – "first" is underlined. * **Line 19:** "over all the 'first class'" – quotes around "first class" are important. * **Line 20:** "work before Sept. If I get" – "Sept." is an abbreviation. * **Line 21:** "through in time, I ex-" – the writing ends abruptly. "ex" I guess. * **Line 22:** "pect to take a flying" – ends the page. I'm double-checking those tricky words: * **"College" (Line 3 & 4):** It's definitely "college," even with the handwriting variations. I will transcribe based on readability. The context makes the intent clear. * **"Of it for..." (Line 6):** I'm pretty sure that faint mark between "of" and "for" is a weak "it" given the idiom. I will include it. * **"Have" (Line 7):** The 'e' looks like a scribbled 'r', but "have" is correct. * **"Sent" (Line 16):** It could read "sut", but "sent" is the clear intent. I will transcribe to standard. * **"Class" (Line 19):** Old-style 'ss' but it's "class". * **"Ex" (Line 21):** The edge of the text is here. I'm thinking about punctuation: Periods, commas, the underline under "first", and the quotes around "first class". I'm using `

they may take will be
for the best interests of
the college. I very much
fear that the college will
have

[Margin: trip to Ky]

Should I find any stumps
that I cant uproot this
summer may I call on
you for some assistance
I will try to get along
without assistance
as I think it will be better
for me to do my own work.

Would you advise me to
use a key to the Mech. or
not. I think I can work
any of these problems out
if I take sufficient time;
but as I have so little time
and so much
that I wish to do, I thought
it might not pay to spend
the time on them, I
might do this time, as
before, simply mark
them for future con-
sideration.
